text:
Hey <@U088UV6MKFE> <@U093Q4FPEJG> Let’s see if we can find some time to do a root cause analysis or at least come up with some mitigation steps and procedures around the outage yesterday. I know Ferenc already started on that with his postgres change request to IEU. maybe there are other ideas we can come up with too.

Also, we can talk about getting more people in the company, outside eng, involved in the alerting system, so if it all happens on a weird timezone, others can jump in and do something helpful, like ping IEU!

elements.text: Hey

Also, we can talk about getting more people in the company, outside eng, involved in the alerting system, so if it all happens on a weird timezone, others can jump in and do something helpful, like ping IEU!

text:
yeah, and we recovered the rewards from, i’d guess, around half of that downtime.

Still, room for improvement certainly. We are going to meet together today and discuss how to remedy the issue going forward, and generally about an improved notification and coverage plan.

text:
One thing I realized, we could do before Mainnet dlc-attestor-stack version cut:
• add dibtc-chains to the /health report 
• validate the config more strict on startup. Currently, no validation happens on any of the Canton settings, so we won't know if someone misconfigured it, until we try to mint

text:
Here is the bugbounty report for those with no access to remedy.

Here is my take:
I think this is a valid report, and very nicely made with PoC tests. I agree with the triage that it is Medium severity at best (not Critical).
• Historically, the Chainlink PoR feeds have _never_ been stale. Of course, black-swan events are possible, and we should not rely on past performance or trust, and even CL recommends checking for stale data.
• The exploiter must be a whitelisted Merchant. These are trusted KYB-d institutions, with decade-long reputations to uphold. Nevertheless, we should minimize trust, and have on-chain checks as much as possible.
• Most importantly: Note that the setStatusFunded is called by the Attestor Network's multisig. So even if the Merchant is malicious, they need a way to hack a threshold of the Attestors into minting more than was deposited on Bitcoin (so they would call setStatusFunded with a higher amount than what was locked in the reserves. _This_ is the true attack, that a stale feed would enable). Which makes the exploit definitely much much harder to pull off. The on-chain PoR check is the last, final on-chain check for reserves, not the _only_ check.
I would also add, that the insolvency happens _not_ how the reporter lays it out. But it could still be achieved. I can explain if that is of interest.

---------------------------------
So all in all, .... not sure, what do you guys think. One thing I would not tell the reporter is that we don't even have PoR enabled :smile: It should not matter for this report. If we want to deal with iBTC going forward, we should implement the recommended change. And therefore we should pay them something, say $500-$1000 USD to incentivize future reports. IF the two stars align for the exploit to happen, then it is indeed catastrophic
